alert.note: Alert for North Central; Northeast; Northwest; San Juan and Vicinity (Puerto Rico) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS San Juan (San Juan, Puerto Rico)
info.headline: Rip Current Statement issued September 12 at 12:27PM ADT until September 16 at 7:00AM ADT by NWS San Juan
info.description: ...HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH LATE THURSDAY NIGHT... ...HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 3 PM THIS AFTERNOON TO 6 PM AST WEDNESDAY... ...COASTAL FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 9 PM THIS EVENING TO 6 PM AST TUESDAY... * WHAT...Dangerous surf conditions and rip currents expected due to breaking waves of 6 to 10 feet. Breaking waves will peak between 10 and 15 feet late tonight through Tuesday. Beach erosion and isolated coastal flooding is expected especially around high tide. * WHERE...Northern beaches of Puerto Rico. * WHEN...For the High Rip Current Risk, from today through late Thursday night. For the High Surf Advisory, from late today through Wednesday afternoon. For the Coastal Flood Advisory, from this evening to Tuesday. * IMPACTS...Dangerous swimming conditions. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water. Hazardous breaking waves. Isolated coastal flooding and beach erosion. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A long period northerly swell is forecast to reach the Atlantic coastal waters of the islands by this evening. This swell could suddenly produce larger breaking waves along the northern beaches of Puerto Rico during the afternoon hours. Therefore, a High Surf Advisory will go in effect during the mid-afternoon hours. Breaking waves are expected to double in size by tomorrow between 10 and 15 feet, and beach erosion is posible, especially near high tides. Arecibo high tide`s are tonight at 10:07 PM AST and tomorrow around 10:41 AM AST, around 1.64 ft and 1.92, respectively. San Juan high tide`s are tonight at 10:39 PM AST and tomorrow around 11:17 AM AST, around 1.48 ft and 1.73, respectively. Fajardo high tide`s are tonight at 10:20 PM AST and tomorrow around 11:00 AM AST, around 1.42 ft and 1.60, respectively.
info.instruction: A High Surf Advisory means that high surf will affect beaches in the advisory area, producing localized beach erosion and dangerous swimming conditions. There is a high risk of rip currents. Rip currents are powerful channels of water flowing quickly away from shore, which occur most often at low spots or breaks in the sandbar and in the vicinity of structures such as groins, jetties and piers. Heed the advice of lifeguards, beach patrol flags and signs. If you become caught in a rip current, yell for help. Remain calm, do not exhaust yourself and stay afloat while waiting for help. If you have to swim out of a rip current, swim parallel to shore and back toward the beach when possible. Do not attempt to swim directly against a rip current as you will tire quickly. A Coastal Flood Advisory indicates that onshore winds and tides will combine to generate flooding of low areas along the shore.

area.areaDesc: North Central; Northeast; Northwest; San Juan and Vicinity
